sen.j: 院宮分国制（いんぐうぶんこくせい）とは、太上天皇や女院、中宮、斎宮などに除目の際に特定の令制国の受領を推挙する権利を与え、そこから経済的利益の配分を受けることで俸禄の代わりとする制度。
sen.e: Ingubunkokusei is a system in which retired emperors, empresses/women bestowed with the title "in", second consorts of emperors, and imperial princesses serving at the Ise shrine were granted the right at the time of appointment to recommend a provincial governor of a certain province and received in return financial profits in place of salaries.

Ingubunkokusei was a system of granting the right to recommend a provincial governor to a specific province to retired emperors, nyoin (women bestowed with the title "in" (usually the empress, imperial princesses, etc.)), second consorts to the emperor, and imperial princesses serving at the Ise Shrine at the time of their appointment. In return they would receive the financial profits of the provinces in place of a salary.

sen.j: 主に院司が受領に任じられて任国に下って知行国を支配した。
sen.e: Usually, an official of the retired emperor's office was appointed to zuryo, went to the province of the assignment, and controlled that province.

sen.j: 平安時代から南北朝時代_(日本)にかけて置かれていた。
sen.e: This system existed from the Heian period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).
This system existed from the Heian period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

sen.j: その由来については淡路国に流された淡路廃帝大炊親王（淳仁天皇）のために同国の官物・庸調が廃帝の生活に充てられ、平城京に籠った平城上皇のために大和国の田租・地子イネが生活に充てられたもの、更にその後導入された親王任国を制度の嚆矢とする説もある。
sen.e: Theories about the origin of the ingubunkokusei system are as follows: it started when kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes) and choyo (taxes in tribute and labor under the ritsuryo system) collected within Awaji Province were used to feed Imperial Prince Oi called Awaji Haitei (deposed Emperor of Awaji) who was deported to Awaji Province; it started when denso (rice field tax) and rice collected within Yamato Province were used to feed the retired Emperor Heizei who confined himself in Heijo-Kyo; and shinno ninkoku (provinces whose gubernatorial posts were reserved as sinecures for imperial princes) introduced later than the above were the beginning of the system.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: One theory on the origin of the ingubunkokusei system describes that it started when kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes) and choyo (taxes in tribute and labor under the ritsuryo system) collected within Awaji Province were used to feed Imperial Prince Oi who had been deported to the province and called Awaji Haitei (deposed Emperor of Awaji). Another theory argues that the system began when denso (a rice field tax) and rice collected within Yamato Province was used to feed Retired Emperor Heizei who had confined himself in Heijo-Kyo. A third theory states that the system was established along with shinno nintoku (provinces whose governing posts were reserved as sinecures for imperial princes) system that was introduced later on.

sen.j: 延喜8年（908年）に宇多上皇のために信濃国が与えられ、10年後に更に武蔵国が与えられたのが最古の例と考えるのが妥当とされている。
sen.e: However, it is now most commonly believed that the oldest example of use of the system is when Shinano Province was given to the Retired Emperor Uda in 908 and followed by Musashi Province 10 years later.

sen.j: 受領の任期は通常4年であったが、院らは持ち回りによって毎年のように別個の令制国の受領を任じた（4ヶ国の知行国があれば、毎年別の国の受領を推挙・任命することになる）ために「年分受領」とも呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Although the term of zuryo was usually 4 years, the recipients took turns to appoint zuryo to a different province every year (if a zuryo controlled 4 provinces, the recipients could recommend and appoint zuryo in a different province every year) and this caused zuryo to be called 'nenbun zuryo.'
